comment.author: 92033577@N00
comment._content: It's amazing how quickly many search engines "selling something" pick up a public domain image like this one and offer it for sale as a "print". Amazon and the several others are instantly listing this on Google. Important person during WWI ?? -- Seen in my contacts' photos. (?)

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: A Mrs. Barton French was part of the women's committee of the American Ambulance Association, and served as a nurse in Paris during the war: books.google.com/books?id=4ncil8aUjuAC&lpg=PT87&d... Mary Walker Barton French (whose initials match the caption) (1866-1964) was born Mary Walker Fearn, married Seth Barton French first (one son, William), then married a Russian Prince, Sergei Wolkonsky. She was widowed in 1937 and died at age 97 in 1964; she's buried in Richmond VA: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=25552713 Her second husband's wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serge_Wolkonsky Her father's wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walker_Fearn

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/melystu] Actually, they've been doing this since at least when these pictures went online at LOC's site, years before they were put up here.  Too bad the buyers don't know LOC has very hi-res images of these for free.

comment.author: 92033577@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Thanks for the info. I"m not surprised, actually. I know it goes on, generally, for anything on the web that can be sold for wall decoration. Right, too bad they don't know they can go to the source, get a better image, and support their national library--all at once.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Arrived in Hoboken, NJ on the Holland-America liner Rotterdam from England on 12/23/15. see note under

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks so much pennylricharsca and artolog for your great research. We'll add some of the information to the record the next time we update.
